Early Access Review

Football Tactics:
~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Always wanted to find out how the top coaches made it all the way to the Premier League? Well, don‚Äôt look further, they are all playing Football Tactics!!

Football Tactics is a football manager game using a turn-based system during match day which gives this game its originality.

First you will have to choose which team and in which country you will be playing. Then, the Amateur League will start. This league is realistically a tutorial and will help you to understand how to play the game and you will probably find it quite easy. As soon as you move up to the next league, the difficulty will increase straight away and you will be facing tougher opponents. In total, you have 5 leagues and 2 cups to play in and the aim is to reach and win the Premier League and the Cups, of course.

The management aspect of the game has good depth but it is easy to use and understand. I really like it that way. You can . . . upgrade your stadium to get more attendance and revenue, upgrade your youth academy so you can find better young talents, purchase new players during the transfer window, get specific coaches and assistants so your players improve their skills (but you will need prestige points). How do you get prestige points, you may ask? Really simple, if the goal difference is  1 in your favour then you will get 1 prestige point. If you manage to finish the season in the top 3 teams, you will be rewarded with additional prestige points.

Match day ‚Äì Each half will consist of 24 action moves to be used between each team, with a total of 48 moves per match. Remember, you and your opponent will use 3 action moves per turn. They are plenty of moves to make your mark and score goals. At the end of each match, your player will get experience points which in turn will help them to reach a higher level. If you win, you‚Äôll get higher experience points.

The graphics are smooth and polished and the game runs well. This game is an early access and it is very impressive so far. Please bring on the full version, I can‚Äôt wait!

-	Really fun to play

I've been in love with football management sims since the days of One-Nil[www.myabandonware.com]. That's 1992, my friends.
I've never enjoyed one as much as this one.

This game is simple enough to play that you can jump right in and start playing. And if you want a casual experience, you can play this game like that. Don't think too much about your decisions, just pick what feels right. You can do that and have fun.

Or, if you want a more analytical experience, you can take your time over each decision.
You can put your roster into a spreadsheet, plan out which players you will develop and which ones you will sell, and when.
You can crunch the numbers over the tactical decisions in the match. Do I take a shot from long range with my ACC 52 midfielder against his DEF 67 keeper, or is it better if I try a layoff pass through his center back to my forward, who can then try to score with a rainbow feint? You can do the math and figure out which one has a better chance at a goal--and also think about what position you leave the opponent with if you do not get a goal.

In other words, you can play this game hardcore, and try to make the best decisions all the time (even though many of the decisions will defy exhaustive analysis), or you can play by the seat of your pants, and try to win by instincts. It is a remarkable acheivement to have created a game that can satisfy both types of play styles.

You will like this game if you like:
Turn-based tactics and strategy. (Even if you aren't a football fan, you will like this aspect, if you like turn-based squad tactics at all.)
Roster management--balancing the need to win matches now with the need to develop your next generation of players.
Elegant game design--something simple to learn, but deceptively complex beneath the surface. Every decision that confronts you offers enough options to be interesting, but not so many to be overwhelming.
The challenge of taking the worst club in the lowest league and slowly building it into a continental champion.
Replayability--start over with a new club and try a different strategy.
Real club names and logos. It takes only a couple minutes to download the user mods with real names and logos for all of the clubs in all of the leagues. After all, isn't it more fun to take over West Bromwich Albion, with the throstle-on-a-hawthorn-branch logo, than some club named West Bromwich FC represented by a generic green eagle silhoutted atop a soccer ball?

This is a very fun game. It is simple and elegant yet there is enough depth in the mechanics to provide good satisfication. EDIT
Okay I now have 10+ hours under my belt. So I just want to update this. I can confirm that the greater variety of skills as your team progresses increases the depth of the game and I'm still only in Division 2  so I imagine as I unlock some more or get better players that this will continue to increase.

And I stand by my impressions from the beta demo. This is a very clever game design. It's easy to understand mechanics and interface but there is still a good deal of strategy involved.

Now it's still not perfect.

At the moment, the lowest two divisions are a push over but they have said they are going to update the game with a choice of weaker teams to start with for greater difficulty. It's good in a way because it gives you time to learn the game and it's far from overwhelming. It's also not such a problem because the amauter league(lowest league) season is shorter than the higher divisions. That and you get more fame points (which you use to upgrade some aspects of your club) the more you win by so you are still interested in doing well even if the amaetur league doesn't really threaten to win the games.

The AI does the occassional silly thing but it's no where near enough to ruin the experience.

Finally I had my first crash just recently but it was after 10+ hours of play and 3 seasons in so it seems very stable for early access.

I could have talked in more details about why I think the game is so cleverly designed and why this is a gem but this is already going on to long and I just want to be upfront. It's definetely worth the price, even in early access.

Early Access Review

Well I always really liked the idea of a Football game (soccer in America) and I actually own quite a few of those games.

But the problem I always had is the management was more of a headache and a bit too complex, and the actual football game (where you watch/play the game) was a bit too boring and drawn out.

This game seems to have found a perfect 'level' of things, at least for me.
The management is just the right amount of complexity where you feel like you are managing your team, but not so much complexity that you're too overwhelmed.

And the games are engaging as you have to manage your 'tactics' ;) to move the ball around and get a goal, and controlling each player in a turn-based fashion and stuff like this is just satisfying all around.

I really look forward to seeing the game grow and develop just a little bit more.
(in particular the multiplayer as well as a few little tweaks to the game that are being mentioned on the forums already)

For those curious how the actual matches work, there are a number of features and things that make it quite nicely complex, without being overwhelming.

Every 'turn' in game is 2 minutes of time that goes by, out of the 45 minutes x2 halves.
Each team gets 3 turns in a row, before passing control to the opposing team, you can end your 3-turn segment early
if you wish.

Each player has different skills, accuracy, control, defense, etc.. and these skills come into play, for example, when 'crossing' an opposing player in a match.
So for example the opponent player has control of the ball.. and you want to take it from him.
So you move your player up adjacent to the opposing player with the ball, using one of your three actions.
Then you attempt to 'wrestle' the ball from him.
Depending on each of your skill in Control, a dice will be rolled for each player, with a maximum possible roll depending on skill.
So for example say the opponent with the ball has a maximum 'potential' roll of 30.
Your 'attacking' player has a maximum potential roll of 25.
You attempt to wrestle the ball, the dice is rolled (in the background, doesn't actually show the dice) then you roll a 25 (lucky) bu the opponent only rolls a 20.. you are successful at wrestling the ball from him, despite having lower skill.
But it was still risky.

With your third and last action you kick the ball towards the goal.
There are several defense men and the goalie in the way.
Each one has a maximum potential to block, and you have your potential to successfully kick.
You roll a 20.. then the first defense player rolls a 15, then the second a 7, then the goalie a 17.
Then that's it, the ball goes through and YOU SCORE!!!

The matches are  engaging, the management is deep but not overly so.
The game is just fun, and I can't wait for MP to be added, cause if done right, will make this game just great.

Dev's are listening to minor issues, and improvements suggestions on the forums, and are very active.

I highly recommend this game if you're looking for a good Football/Soccer experience that's fun and easy to get into,
and possibly have been burned by other Football/Soccer games that were just too boring and un-engaging.

I‚Äôm such a big fan of Sports Interactive‚Äòs Football Manager that when Creoteam approached me to cover their Football Tactics game rather than another game that I was hoping to feature developed by them that I was more than a little skeptical. Nothing is as in depth, serious and addictive in regards to football management games as good old FM. I‚Äôve played many hours in a number of other management games that attempt to push FM off of its porch but nothing has ever come close. I feared that Creoteam‚Äôs game was just going to end up being just another game that tried its best but fell woefully short. Thankfully I was quickly alleviated of my fears when I realized that that wasn‚Äôt what they were attempting to do at all. What their intention to create was a football management game that was much more accessible to all gamers ‚Äì not just football super fans ‚Äì as well as a game that was much more casual and nature and just an overall fun gaming experience.

In many ways Football Tactics reminded me of a few of the older shareware football management games that I played in my teenage years. These were games that were nowhere close to the uber tight management games that FM and Out of the Park Baseball are producing today but they were games that I vividly remember sinking tens or even hundreds of hours into.  For a gamer and a sports nut this game has the potential, and already is for its stage of early access, to be a lot of fun. You don‚Äôt need everything to uber serious all of the time so the game is going to fit a very nice niche.

The game plays out similarly to turn based combat games do on a grid with the obvious difference being that its football rather than an action-strategy game. Players have various different skills that are what you would expect from a football player with special skills such as shot cannon, lob passes, etc. giving the game some spice and flavor. Games are relatively quick affairs with some players feeling that they‚Äôre a little too short so perhaps an option to extend the game‚Äôs length ‚Äì which many sports titles currently allow ‚Äì perhaps being a nice option to appease them. I‚Äôd also like to see some more options within the game ‚Äì a few more moves added. However, I‚Äôve just been promoted out of the first league so more advanced techniques and skill may start becoming available as I progress during the game.

I like the amount of options that have been developed outside of matches themselves. The full gamut of options for a football fan are present. You can play the transfer market ‚Äì buying better players and selling those that have been made redundant. You can also upgrade your club in a number of different ways. You can increase your seating capacity which will in turn increase the amount of money that you take at the gate. Improving your youth academy allows you to get better young footballers into the club. The first scout assistant decreases the age of players on the transfer list while the second scout assistant increases the number of players on the transfer list. Improving your major assistant enables substitutes to get experience after a match and finally positional coaches increase the amount of experience players get following matches.

The game is already heavily Steamified with 51 achievements giving hunters something to aim for and there are eleven trading cards to get to collect a full set. Steam Workshop integration has already been added to the game so that players can create mods, leagues and other things to improve the game. Finally, leagues can be played by both a single player or multi player to add a more competitive spirit to the game. In all, I‚Äôm very impressed with the amount of work that has already been completed on the game. The game is feature complete as Creoteam promise but they want to add even more features and tools to the game to make it the best game that it can possibly be and that makes me excited.

Although it probably wont replace Football Manager as my go to football management game it is a game that I return to time and again to experience its casual, smart and very well designed and develop footballing experience. A great game.

This game was originally an iOS title, normally when you see that on a Steam review it's synonymous with a bad port and terrible gameplay, not this time. I'm not sure under what circumstances the first iteration of this game folded but I'm glad it's back and that the developers seem to be really trying to make it work this time around.

GAMEPLAY: Take chess, take football, take a little from strategy games like Blood Bowl and that's what this game is. I've been trying to get into Blood Bowl for quite some time but I find it too obscure and complicated. This has potentially a very rich tactical depth but is at the same time super easy to understand and after a couple matches you'll realize what the best strategies are (once PvP is introduce that depth will turn into a black hole of infinite posibilities). Also, it's nice because it feels like a full fledged turn based experience but every match can be played in a very short amount of time.

INTERFACE: It's super obvious this is a port from a tablet game, but the developer has said they'll eventually introduce widescreen support. Other than that, I'm not bothered at all by the app feel of the interface, it would be awesome if they launched on iOS again and you could continue your league play on the go.

OTHER: In its previous model, this game had a pay mechanic to grant you access to the best players, I never entered the PvP scene because the app crashed all the time and it was super annoying so I didn't inverst into it but that mechanic has been removed (at least until version 0.2). Oh and apparently they are working on Workshop support to personalize the content even further.

To improve until final release:

-Widescreen support
-PvP as soon as possible
-Certain minor bugs here and there (the developers seem active in correcting them though)

My wishlist:

-Local hotseat support
-The ability to play with selected teams already at the top
-Multiple save slots

TL;DR: If you like strategy games and you like football this game is the real deal. Best case scenario, you invest 13 bucks for a game that will eventually become a monster in strategy and sports gaming (the core gameplay certainly has the potential for that). Worst case scenario, the developers give up tomorrow and you invest 13 bucks in an amazing single player experience that even right now is very polished and very addicting.

Early Access Version 0.2 review:

Let me start by saying I am not much of a football fan at all. I mean I'll follow the world cup highlights, but that's about as far as I go. As far as gaming goes, I last seriously played Footbal Manager on Commodore 64, as later PC versions turned out just too tedious for me.

But then I came across this. And *boom*, I love football again. Well done Creoteam, really well done. Why is it so good? Because it is simple, yet deep. Easy to grasp, but will take cunning and skill to master.

First I spent an hour deciding on my club's name, fiddling with the colours and jerseys, then it plunges you straight into the competition. Only a few tabs, like the team roster with the basic pitch layout and who you want to play where, the training menu with just a couple options for each player, the buying/selling transfers one, the upgrade one and the league table and calendar. Nothing to get lost in, easy to keep all your players in mind and how to best use them in a game.

And the game? A brilliantly simple concept.  3 actions per turn when you can try to take the ball from the other team, pass it, dribble or shoot. The skill of your player vs. the skill of the opposing player will determine if you will be successful. But whenever you score a goal, you're genuinely happy, because you executed a tactic perfectly.

Even at version 0.2 the game is perfectly playable, the looks and animations are excellent for a simple-graphics game, you'll probably want to turn off the repetitive music after a half an hour, but otherwise it's great fun.

A match takes about 3-4 minutes to complete and time just flies away as you need to play just one more game.

Its easy to play and far less complicated than chess, in fact its the light aspect of it which perhaps is the games biggest advantage, everyone can pick it up and have a go. As for the price, given the hours I have use I cant complain.

The devs seem responsive and the beta has many new implementations which improve the game, youth academy, other ways of gaining fame (game currency for certain upgrades). Up to you to give the current release a go or try the beta.

With much room for improvements and balance I still think this is a little gem, if you are a football fan you might love it.

Early Access Review

The problem with Football Tactics, simply put, is that it lacks depth. At its core this is supposed to be a turn based strategy game, yet it also tries to be as casual as possible. The movement is limited by the small pitch size and the relatively small choice of actions means that you'll be doing the same things over and over again. Since the game is heavily reliant on RNG you will usually have to play the numbers to have a shot at a consistently succesful season, which further limits your influence on the proceedings. Your players will, for large parts of the game, have only one skill and most situations are dictated by a singular attribute, so your decisions usually get simplified even further.
Progress mostly comes from player stats, which give the game an RPG~ish touch, yet also seem to be mostly random. You can buy and sell players, but due to the way finances are set up you'll want to grow your own, which mostly means getting decent young players and leveling them up. Upon level up the player gets a semi random set of stat upgrades. Level ups come quite regularly but are usually pretty meager on their own (+1 to your primary stat seems to be the average), which means building up a team to take on the best opposition is a lengthy undertaking.

On the plus side these may be things some players look for. There's minimal input on your end and yet, through unnecessarily grindy upgrades, there's some sense of progress (which you will attribute to your skill, even though you know better). I've put quite a few hours into the game while watching Netflix on my primary screen and I have to admit it's a great fit for that. The UI/graphics are simple yet pleasant and while the audio is laughable it's fortunately entirely irrelevant. It isn't punishing at all, there is no fail state and it will reward you just for being there, which I personally fail to appreciate but can still potentially see other people enjoying.

Maybe I went in expecting the wrong thing. I read the name as if there was an emphasis on tactics, I thought of great games like Frozen Cortex or even Blood Bowl and while I never expected the game to have that kind of quality, this was stilll a huge let-down. I spent more than ten hours with it hoping for the game to improve towards the late game, but its inherently simple design stops it from ever becoming more than a casual side activity. I'd expect this kind of game to be on a mobile platform for around five bucks and I'd recommend it to the crowd that goes for those. For people looking for anything more than a time-killer I'd suggest staying away.

Football Tactics is a simple game of football team management and coaching. The goal, pun intended, is to move your club into the premier league of your nation to compete for the top championship. It will appeal to players who are fans of football and players whose time is limited to 30 minute play sessions. That‚Äôs about all the time you need to set your line, make a few improvements to your club, and play a match or two in Football Tactics.

Compared to other football management sims, this game is simpler. For example, the footballers who populate your club‚Äôs lines have only four rated skills:  accuracy for shooting goals, passing to other teammates, defense for taking the ball from your opponents, and control for mainlining possession during an opponent‚Äôs defensive action. However, these four skills, tactics cards, tactics formations, and your players‚Äô age and energy level create on field challenges that are deeper than expected.

The matches are turn-based with each team alternating through 3 actions per side for a set number of actions per half. During one cycle you might have a mid-fielder pass to a forward, the forward dribble to get  a better shot angle, and then the forward make a precision shot on goal. Of course, the opposing team will try to counter your moves each step of the way.

Off the field, club mangers can shop the transfer market, direct player training and development, and oversee expansion of the team‚Äôs fan base, coaching staff, and facility upgrades. The business model is easy to understand. The better players perform on the field the higher their price and trade value rises.  Put together a string of victories and your club‚Äôs fan base will grow helping you earn more from ticket sales for home games. In addition to money, your team will also earn prestige points that you can spend on team management decisions.

Football Tactics includes stock leagues from around the world in addition to a growing number of national and international leagues that users are adding on Steam Workshop. If you don‚Äôt like your club‚Äôs name, kit, or logo, then you‚Äôre free to modify them in the in-game editor. Also, you can edit the names of team members, too.

The Skinny: Good polish to an interesting concept tagged and labeled as a genre bending tactical/strategy/rpg/sports simulation game. Confusing design decisions caused this title to suffer an identiy crisis deciding if it was going to be a casual or hardcore. Worse still the developers failed to circumvent some of the pitfalls that come with combining so many concepts together.

Even More Skinny: This game feels alot like a very polished mobile phone freemium game without the microtransactions.

I do of course approve of the developers excluding the microtransactions and the care they have taken in refining their product to be presented in a a concise and easy-to-use package.

The Longer View:

Tough game to pin down and fit into a Box but I will give it a shot...

I would say this game is a Sports Simulation first and then a Strategy game consisting of some Turn-based RPG elements with a strong Tactical component. Conceptually it seems like an excellent foundation from which you could start building a very unique and deep game but I did not find there to be much complexity to any of the mechanics that were built on top of that great foundation. To me the concept of the game suggests and hints that this is going to be a hardcore crowd pleaser. However, from a presentation standpoint the UI, graphic design, and simplistic text descriptions of events/outcomes/etc. are all much more in line with a casual gaming experience usually found on a mobile phone or facebook game.  I can honestly say that I enjoy both casual phone games (the higher quality ones at least) and hardcore pc games. I will also say that all of the genre's I mentioned earlier are favorites of mine. but I feel that this game comes up short in the areas that usually make each of those genres fun and appealing.


I Liked:

Unique Concept
Player agency in chosing between a few different methods to build your squad
Tactics (I personally am going to buy your game if this is in the title and the screenshots/playthroughs/video is anything short of atrocious)
RPG Elements blended with the Sports Simulator
UI and controls are streamlined perfectly (really well done)
No Microtransactions

AC/DC:

Predomintly a Casual Game
Medium-to-High RNG elements
Grindy
Sound Effects/Music - I would say this aspect was OK but also somewhat sparse and repetitive (I play most sim games listening to a soundtrack of my own choosing anyway)

But awwwwww C'mon:

4 attributes are just not enough.....unless you have an excellent system of Special Abilites to compliment them...
Special Abilities are a bit vanilla and many of the defensive ones pointless
No real storyline feel and very limited options for customizations to create your own"
Small size of the playing field grid limits options
Very Limited Defensive Options
Feels like a Hardcore Gaming Input is required b/c....
Progression is slow and incrimental
Difficutly/Balancing Staggered Resulting in Long Periods of cruising followed by getting your face crushed once you've hit a (non-pay) wall
Juxtaposition of the two points immediately above this one

That last point was the real fun killer for me. Football Tactics fails in this regard by setting itself up with a freemium game structure in that you are either struggling to progress because you have not inserted enough currency (in this case time spent grinding) or blowing the competition out of the water because you have. The tactical aspects of games will occasionally allow for you to beat a superior opponent and it is at the moment Football Tactics shines brightest. This too comes with a pitfall unfortunately because of the limited amount of diversity offered in your player builds and to a lesser degree limited number of spaces and therefore movement on the field. The result is that there are a limited number of choices to your strategies and many of them will come down to attempting a similiar set of actions that rely more on maximizing your best chance at a good roll (RNG haters beware) than careful planning. I really felt like I was being punished by the game for succeeding with these tactics early on as it caused my squad to advance up the divisions twice in concurent seasons and left my underfunded squad facing more difficult odds (literally rng odds not tactical difficulties)
than any tactical approach would be able to sufficiently overcome.

Two comparision points I would like to bring up are the statistical heavy Football Manager Series and Tactical Aspects of Blood Bowl.  In a way I feel like Football Tactics is alot like playing a toned down version of the Football Manager series when your simulating games managing your squad
recommended:
or youth player discoveries or in-squad development. The depth of the systems for Football Manager is really what makes it a game worth playing in the first place and again the lack of options present in Football Tactics prevents it from succeeding in the same way. As a Tactical Game Blood Bowl succeeds in the importance of placing your units in the correct spot is crucial because you are making a choice of influencing some control over a large amount of space (by spreading your characters out) or influencing a greater amount of control over a smaller area (keeping your units closer together). Football Tactics gives your units VERY limited influence over space and gives you a very limited field with which to work. When your opponent has the ball most of your units can only influence the space they occupy by being giving a chance to steal the ball if your opponent chooses to challenge that space by dribbling through it or passing almost directly through it. Most of the time this will not factor in as your opponent will choose to forgoe any chance of an interception by making a very safe pass (when a more direct approach is necessary in terms of scoreline/time managment) or simply dribbling past your player. Defenders have the ability to influence shots that cross the spot next to them which is a good start but why do they allow the ball carrier to dribble into that same space without interference? This is a game that can't really seem to decide if it's hardcore or casual.  It's a fun little game that can be great when your tactics make a difference, but too often there is very little you can do to impact the outcome of a game.  Too often the team with the highest numbers wins.  Worse still, a team with a single incredibly good striker or goalkeeper can essentially prevent you from winning if their randomly generated stats are high enough.  Skills have some use, but from what I've seen, they tend to be more situational than part of an overarching style. The game could be good with a few more improvements.

My Feedback:

-Let us start in any league we want.  What's the point of having a Champions League stand in if we always have to start in the 5th division?  Since the game has no microtransactions, why make content so hard to get to?  Some people won't want to level grind all the way to the top.

-Let us pick which abilities our footballers develop.  I really like the layoff pass and rainbow feint abilities, yet who can get these abilities is left up to chance since you have to buy a player before you can devlop an ability.  Players that come with skills seem to be far above my budget.

-Make power shot more viable.  I've seen the difference between power and finesse be 20 points apart for the keeper.  Getting corners is the advantage of the power shot, but it's really hard to weigh the chance of of a richochet against the higher probability of scoring off of a precision shot.  Right now it's now much of a value proposition.

-Continuing off the last point, maybe show us a percentage of a pass or shot working?  How bad is a 20 againt 35? Like it could work, but it's unlikely or more of a pray to the RNG gods type choice? Strategy games are supposed to be about trade offs, but it's often hard to understand some of the x2 moves against one dice roll.

-Revamp the match sim engine.  Right now the same teams keep yo-yoing between divisions.  The teams at the top absolutely clobber the teams at the bottom.  I shouldn't have to have a near perfect record to get promoted.  Especially when a game like this is heavily based on chance.

I wish steam had a neutral button for games like this.  It's not a bad game at all, but I would be hard pressed to recommend it.

Here's a question: did you like Blitzball in Final Fantasy X? No? Would you have liked it if it were... better?

If so, Football Tactics may just be the game for you. It's a super addictive management sim that's leagues simpler than Football Manager.

Grain of salt warning: At the time of this review, Football Tactics is an early access game, so stuff's still being balanced.

Pros:
-The unique player abilities definitely add a bit of spice to the RNG.
-The interface is super clean and easy to read
-Actual matches are fun. I also enjoy the AI mode for when I get burned out and want to play while I'm doing something else. It's nice that you can take control if you think your AI are being stupid, too.
-I like the versatility of being able to use players in non-native positions, like using a Defender as a Midfielder. It really allows you to mix up your team and tactics.
-Hot Seat multiplayer?! I don't think I'll ever get a chance to use it, but I'm pretty excited about it anyway.
-Like a billion real countires and teams to pick from. You can also customize your club's logo and uniforms.

Cons:
-The difficulty curve is a little wacky. You start out in the noobie league, so it's understandably easy. If you do some smart team management, the next league is ok too. Once you hit Second League, you're likely to have a 1.5-star team regularly going up against 2-3 star teams, both in the tournament and the cup. When you tie or lose, your players get fewer XP. Fewer XP means you don't level as quickly. Not leveling means you're grinding in autopilot way longer than you need to be. To my knowledge, there's no way to move backward to lower leagues to train your players. As it is, It kind of feels like an intentinal time sink.
-Addendum: As you move to higher leagues, you get more XP for losing, but your players have time limits on their careers. You can get starting players as young as 16 or 17, but they retire at 35-40.
-CORNER KICKS. I don't know if it's the load time as players get into position, or having to manually move each defender for coverage, or the fact that high-powered teams have a habit of getting 3-5 of them in a row, even with my roided out goalie. Corner kicks are my #1 motivator to spectate matches.
-Also, it'd be cool to swap BACK to spectator mode after taking control. Sometimes I only want to play Offense, or to avoid a Corner Kick or whatever.

But really, this game is super fun. Also, it's cheap, and worth sinking a good 5-10 hours into, at least.

Football Tactics is quite a decent casual game that you can pick up anytime and/or get addicted to.

The game mechanics work on a simple duelling premise between two players across 4 player stats (Accuracy, Passing, Defence, Control), with the addition of several skills/abilities which can turn the game in your favour.

Being an indie title, obviously there is no licencing for official team/player names, which isn't an issue for me or likely anybody that spent their childhood playing Pro Evolution Soccer. There are a number of things you can upgrade for your club (stadium, scouts, coaches, etc.) to help improve the players you have and club finances. However, it becomes a bit of a grind and there is a lack of variety to the gameplay beyond this.

Overall, it's likely to keep you entertained for a little while, or a bit longer if you multi-task like me and play the game sporadically in addition to doing other things. There's a lot of potential with this title and I would expect Football Tactics 2" at some point
